Comments_List: Lots about radiation, not too much about molecules.
This course gave  practical insight into the quantum mechanics behind spectroscopy. Often, comparisons with classical mechanics were used to aid and reinforce learning.
From the foundations of E&M through multi-electron systems and their interactions in spectroscopy.

Mark seemed to put a lot of effort into making sure we fully understood the concept, beginning from the basics and building up. The assignments, although challenging, proved to be very helpful. The organization of the course could be improved, with refined/revised notes for the future of the course.

The course content was interesting and useful, and the workload was not overwhelming. The biggest weakness of the course was that it was sometimes very disorganized. However, this lack of structure allowed for aspects (such as the problem sets) to be improved as the course progressed.

Building from the foundations of E&M up through spectroscopy provided a much more complete picture of the science of spectroscopy than generally happens. The use of analogies and visualizations to describe the concepts was very helpful.

The biggest weakness is that sometimes the transitions from one topic to the next lacked clear connection and needed to be reiterated.
Summarizing  was often done at the beginning of the class about the previous class. Doing this at the end of class with info fresh in our heads would help to solidify the topics discussed.
Yes. It is very useful for an intro to electronics, optics, and spectroscopy.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in spectroscopy and/or physical chemistry, as the content is interesting and relevant
For any student using spectroscopy this course is highly valuable, particularly for those building lasers.
